conclusion: To determine when the object's velocity is at its maximum, we need to analyze the acceleration-time graph provided.
The graph shows the acceleration a (in m/s^2) as a function of time t (in seconds).
The initial acceleration is 2 m/s^2 from t = 0 to t = 1 second.
From t = 1 to t = 3 seconds, the acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s^2 to -2 m/s^2.
From t = 3 to t = 4 seconds, the acceleration remains constant at -2 m/s^2.
Velocity is the integral of acceleration with respect to time.
Initially, the object starts from rest, so the initial velocity v(0) = 0.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the acceleration is constant at 2 m/s^2.
The velocity at t = 1 second is v(1) = 2 m/s.
From t = 1 to t = 3 seconds, the average acceleration is 0 m/s^2.
The velocity remains constant at 2 m/s during this interval.
From t = 3 to t = 4 seconds, the acceleration is constant at -2 m/s^2.
The velocity at t = 4 seconds is 0 m/s.
The velocity increases from 0 to 2 m/s from t = 0 to t = 1 second.
The velocity remains constant at 2 m/s from t = 1 to t = 3 seconds.
The velocity decreases back to 0 from t = 3 to t = 4 seconds.
The object's velocity is at its maximum from t = 1 second to t = 3 seconds.
